title: 115_hr3332
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bob Dole Congressional Gold Medal Act". Bob Dole, born in 1923 in Kansas, learned hard work and discipline during the Great Depression. He attended the University of Kansas, where he excelled in sports and received the "Man of the Year" award from his fraternity. Interrupted by WWII, Dole enlisted in the Army and was wounded in Italy, receiving two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star. Bob Dole received two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star for his service in WWII. He later served in the Kansas House of Representatives, U.S. House of Representatives, and U.S. Senate, holding various leadership positions. Bob Dole, known for bipartisanship and advocacy for the disabled, set records as the longest-serving Republican Leader in the Senate. He was honored by several Presidents, including receiving the Presidential Citizens Medal from President Reagan in 1989. Senator Bob Dole has served America heroically, standing for integrity, straight talk, and achievement. President Clinton awarded him the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1997, praising his understanding of the American people and his efforts to keep America united and strong during times of conflict and crisis. After his career in public office, Bob Dole became an active advocate for the public good. He raised millions for the National WWII Memorial and Families of Freedom Scholarship Fund, served on the International Commission on Missing Persons, and established The Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas. Bob Dole, a strong advocate for international justice, received the Golden Medal of Freedom in 2004 for his support of democracy in Kosovo. In 2007, he co-chaired the President's Commission on Care for America's Returning Wounded Warriors. Dole also co-created the McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program, receiving the World Food Prize in 2008 for his work. Bob Dole is a co-founder of the Bipartisan Policy Center and a strong advocate for veterans. He serves as Finance Chairman of the Campaign for the National Eisenhower Memorial and has been acknowledged for his achievements in politics and public service. Bob Dole has received numerous awards and honors throughout his life-long service to the country, including the Good Citizenship Award, the American Patriot Award, the Survivor's Gratitude Award, and many others. He is recognized for embodying the American spirit of leadership and determination, serving as a prolific role model in and outside of politics. Bob Dole is to receive a Congressional Gold Medal for his service as a soldier, legislator, and statesman. The medal will be designed by the Secretary of the Treasury. Duplicates in bronze may be struck and sold under specific regulations to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code, and considered numismatic items under sections 5134 and 5136 of title 31, United States Code.
